body:
Comment 1: 
Floating point numbers cannot represent Pi or Pi/2 completely precisely.
If you print a float64 with the %.1000g format, it will show the exact
decimal number that _is_ being represented.

If we adjust your program thus:


package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"math"
)

func main() {
	v := 0.5 * math.Pi
	fmt.Printf("%.1000g\n%.1000g\n", v, 2*v)
	fmt.Printf("%.1000g\n", math.Cos(v))
}

then it prints

1.5707963267948965579989817342720925807952880859375
3.141592653589793115997963468544185161590576171875
6.123031769111886291057089692912995815277099609375e-17

It turns out that Pi/2 is closer to
1.5707963267948966192313216916397514420985846996875529

The difference between this real Pi/2 and the closest
float64 (as printed by the program) is about
0.0000000000000000612323399573, or 6.123e-17

Thus, you're not actually calling Cos(Pi/2), because that
is impossible: you're calling Cos(Pi/2 - 6.123e-17), and
for small x, Cos(Pi/2 - x) is approximately x, so Cos
is actually returning an appropriate answer.

Just to double-check, we can take that Pi/2 value that
was printed by the Go program and ask Wolfram Alpha what 
it's cosine is:

http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Cos%5B1.5707963267948965579989817342720925807952880859375%5D
says
6.123233995736765886130329661375001 Ã— 10^-17

The output you got:
6.123233995736757e-17
is thus remarkably accurate.  The output I showed above
was for a run using the 386 compiler, which uses the x87
cosine instruction, which is less accurate.  Either is
more accurate than returning 0, though.

If you need to get an actual 0 for some input, then I suggest
using Sin(x-Pi/2) as your function instead of Cos(x).
